title: PhD and MS Assistantships in Forest Soils and Biogeochemistry
location: College of Forestry, Wildlife and Environment (auburn, Alabama)
description:
PhD and MS Assistantships in Forest Soils and Biogeochemistry
Auburn University (State) | https://cfwe.auburn.edu/profile/?smid=29361
Details
Application Deadline:
08/31/2025
Published:
07/10/2025
Starting Date:
between 1/1/2026 and 6/15/2026
Hours per Week:
at most 40
Salary:
$23,500 to $26,500 per year
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
at least 2 years
Location:
College of Forestry, Wildlife and Environment (auburn, Alabama)
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
Overview 
The Forest Soils and Biogeochemistry Lab at Auburn University (AU) is seeking one PhD student and one MS student to perform research associated with soil biogeochemistry and forest health in the Southeast region. The two graduate students will work together and supervise undergraduates in the field and laboratory to 
1. Assess soil physicochemical properties and microbial activities under repeated prescribed fires and forest thinning 
2. Analyze existing, multi-decadal vegetation and litter data to explore plant-soil-microbe interactions in a changing environment 
3. Examine the impact of microplastic pollution on soil nutrients and microbes. 

The hired students are expected to join and lead a three-week field campaign in summer 2026. The team will travel to multiple field sites and research stations in the southeast (AL, GA, NC, SC) to collect and pre-process soil and litter samples. Samples will be brought or shipped back to AU for further laboratory analysis. Students are welcome to build their projects within the scope of soil health and nutrient cycling.  
 Responsibilities 
1. Conduct literature reviews and learn/develop experimental protocols 
2. Attend weekly or biweekly lab meetings to share updates and give comments 
3. Generate, organize, and analyze data 
4. Write and publish manuscripts in peer-reviewed scientific journals 
5. Present research findings at local, national, and international conferences 
 Minimum Qualifications 
1. BS degree in Forestry, Ecology, Environmental Science, Natural Resources, or a related field; MS degree is required if applying for PhD 
2. Meet admission standards for the Auburn University Graduate School (https://graduate.auburn.edu/); International applicants please visit https://graduate.auburn.edu/prospective-students/general-admission-requirements/ for English language score requirements 
3. Ability to work independently and with others as a team 
 Preferred Qualifications 
1. Ability to locate study sites/plots using GPS units and maps 
2. Soil, water, and vegetation sampling experience 
3. Soil geochemical and microbial analysis experience 
4. Quantitative skills and writing experience 
5. Valid driver's license (or ability to obtain one in several months) 
 Estimated Start Date and Stipend 
PhD student, January 2026, $26,500 per year + tuition remission and benefits 
MS student, June 2026, $23,500 per year + tuition remission and benefits 
Financial support is typically provided for four years for PhD and two years for MS, subject to annual evaluation.  
 About Forest Soils and Biogeochemistry Lab 
Research in the Forest Soils and Biogeochemistry Lab investigates the fate of carbon and other elements in forest soil and its surrounding environment to address soil conservation issues and develop sustainable practices. We integrate field measurements, laboratory experiments, and computational statistics to examine soil biogeochemical responses under warmer climate, shifted precipitation regimes, and disturbances in forest ecosystems. The lab consists of a main laboratory room, a soil texture room, two storage rooms with field equipment, and a shared walk-in refrigerator. The main laboratory room houses a Biological Digital Microscope, a Deionized Water System, a Shimadzu Total Organic Carbon Analyzer, an Electronic Thermostat Hova-Bator Incubator, an Isotemp Programmable Muffle Furnace, a Chloroform fumigation-extraction station, and a brand-new FlashSmart Elemental Analyzer.

Visit Dr. Yang’s profile to learn more about the lab and research activities. Information regarding PhD and MS programs in the college of Forestry, Wildlife and Environment can be found at https://cfwe.auburn.edu/graduate-study/graduate-degrees/. 
 To Apply
Please email the following materials as a single PDF document to Dr. Yang Yang at yangy@auburn.edu, with the subject line “Potential Graduate Student at AU.” 
1. A cover letter (1 page max) outlining the research interests, relevant experience, and professional goals 
2. Resume/CV and contact information only from three professional references 
3. Unofficial transcripts 

Applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis and accepted through August 31, 2025. If selected, the applicant(s) will be invited for a short virtual interview before submitting a complete application. A complete application includes a cover letter, Resume/CV, official transcripts, English language score (International students only), and three letters of recommendation. Please reach out with any questions. 

Contact
Dr. Yang Yang
yangy@auburn.edu (preferred contact method)

Description
 MSc Position – Forest Disturbance Ecology & Remote Sensing
 
University of Northern British Columbia
 
Start Date: May or September 2026                                           Location: Prince George, BC

Project Overview

This collaborative project with the British Columbia Ministry of Forests examines how interacting disturbances and climate change are reshaping forest trajectories in northern British Columbia. Focusing on landscapes affected by windthrow, insect outbreaks, and wildfire, the research aims to understand how disturbance severity and legacy effects influence long-term forest resilience.

The MSc student will investigate how disturbance legacies shape regeneration, stand structure, tree growth, and carbon dynamics using a combination of field-based forest surveys, dendrochronology (tree growth analysis), and geospatial tools, including drone-based lidar and satellite remote sensing. The project integrates ecological theory with applied management questions, providing hands-on experience in field ecology, quantitative analysis, and multi-scale disturbance assessment.

Qualifications

·        BSc (or expected completion) in forestry, ecology, environmental science, geography, or related field

·        Interest in forest disturbance ecology and climate change

·        Experience with fieldwork in forest ecosystems

·        Strong quantitative skills (R preferred)

·        Experience with GIS or remote sensing is an asset

·       Willingness to work in remote field conditions

Funding

Funding is anticipated at $20,000 for two years, subject to final confirmation. The student will also be encouraged to apply for scholarships (e.g., NSERC CGS-M, UNBC internal scholarships) and teaching assistantships.

Why UNBC?

UNBC is located in Prince George, the hub of northern British Columbia, offering direct access to diverse forest ecosystems shaped by multiple disturbance regimes. The university is recognized for its strengths in natural resources, forestry, and environmental science. Students benefit from small graduate cohorts, close faculty mentorship, and extensive hands-on field experience. The Natural Resources and Environmental Studies graduate program provides a dynamic hub of students and researchers with a broad range of research interests. Please explore the website for further information: https://www.unbc.ca/nres-graduate-program

Prince George offers an affordable cost of living and outstanding outdoor opportunities, including hiking, skiing, and backcountry access. For students interested in applied forest science and climate change adaptation, UNBC provides an immersive and supportive research environment in a region experiencing real-world forest change.

How to Apply

Please email the following as a single PDF to Dr. Violet Zhao violet.zhao@unbc.ca:
 
·        Brief statement of research interests (1 page max)
 
·        CV
 
·        Unofficial transcripts
 
·       Contact information for two references
 
Review of applications will continue until the position is filled. Applications received by Feb 27 will be given full consideration.
  Contact
Violet Zhao
violet.zhao@unbc.ca (preferred contact method)

title: PhD assistantship: Rio Grande cutthroat trout conservation and genetics
location: New Mexico State University (Las Cruces, New Mexico)
description:
PhD assistantship: Rio Grande cutthroat trout conservation and genetics
New Mexico State University (State)
Details
Application Deadline:
03/18/2026
Published:
02/18/2026
Starting Date:
8/17/2026
Hours per Week:
at least 20
Salary:
$28,384 to $29,041 per year
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
none
Location:
New Mexico State University (Las Cruces, New Mexico)
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
RIO GRANDE CUTTHROAT TROUT PHD ASSISTANTSHIP

Description & project background: 

The Pregler Lab at New Mexico State University in the Department of Fish, Wildlife, and Conservation Ecology invites applications for a PhD research assistantship focused on Rio Grande cutthroat trout conservation. The successful applicant will begin in the Fall 2026 semester.

Rio Grande cutthroat trout (RGCT) are the southernmost species of cutthroat trout and have experienced a severe decline in both range and abundance, now occupying only ~12 percent of its historical distribution and requires targeted management interventions to support recovery. Major components of the recovery plan detail the need to secure extant populations and reintroduce individuals within their native range in Colorado and New Mexico. Recent efforts to date include development of a multi-source, genetically diverse broodstock for the Rio Grande basin that is used for reintroduction efforts.

Individuals from this multi-source broodstock were stocked at multiple sites throughout the recently restored Rio Costilla watershed which represents one of the largest native fish restoration projects in the country. While recent research has shown that this composite broodstock is more genetically diverse compared to using single source populations there is a need to evaluate how these fish are performing in the wild. The present project has a number of goals:

          1. Evaluate genetic structure and diversity of reintroduced Rio Costilla RGCT populations
                     a. There is also opportunity to develop questions with demographic monitoring data in this system.
          2. Genetic assessment of Rio Grande, Canadian, and Pecos basins. 
                     a. Results will help inform multi-source broodstock development for Canadian & Pecos basins and identify additional source populations for Rio Grande basin.
                     b. Results will also provide an updated genetic assessment for RGCT.
          3. There are additional opportunities for the student to develop their own questions using genetic and demographic data.

This project is a collaborative effort funded by the New Mexico Department of Wildlife and there may be potential to collaborate with other university researchers and agencies. Benefits include a salary range of ~$28-29k/year, full tuition waiver, and subsidized health insurance. Funding will also be available for conference travel, workshop training for data analyses, and safety training (e.g., wilderness first aid). The hired candidate will begin in Fall 2026 and will be based at NMSU in Las Cruces, NM.

How to apply: If interested, please compile the following: (1) a statement of interest that describes your educational and research background, as well as your research interests and how this position fits in your career goals (2) curriculum vitae or resume, (3) contact information for three professional references, and (4) unofficial transcripts compiled in a single PDF and save as ‘Lastname_RGCT_PhD.pdf’.  Applicants are also asked to upload a writing sample in the application portal. Applications should be submitted through the airtable linked here:  https://airtable.com/app3jNqbQZsYstwx7/pagrpU5GqaI6FnSTg/form 

Applications are due 03/18/26 by 11:59p MT. You can learn more about the Pregler Lab at https://preglerlab.com and any questions about the position can be sent to Dr. Kasey Pregler at kpregler@nmsu.edu.   

Qualifications: 

Required: B.S. in fisheries, biology, or related field and possession of a valid U.S. driver’s license. The successful applicant must also meet the minimum requirements for admission to the NMSU Graduate School (3.0 GPA in last two years of undergrad). Applicants should also have demonstrated excellent written and oral communication skills, and an ability to work independently. 

Preference will be given to applicants with an M.S. degree in fisheries, biology, or related field and have experience working in the backcountry and are willing to lead field work crews in backcountry conditions.

Successful candidates will have proficiency in R, and an interest in genetics and working with large datasets. They should also demonstrate the ability to work as part of a team and have a willingness to lead field work crews in remote backcountry locations. Applicants with experience in fish ecology, statistical & genetic analysis, and hierarchical modeling are encouraged to apply.  

Salary: 

~$28-29k /year
Full tuition waiver 
Subsidized health insurance

Contact
Kasey Pregler
kpregler@nmsu.edu (preferred contact method)

title: Large Mammal/AI Graduate Assistantship (MS), Colorado State University
description:
Large Mammal/AI Graduate Assistantship (MS), Colorado State University
Colorado State University (State) | https://colostate.edu
Details
Application Deadline:
03/02/2026
Published:
02/18/2026
Starting Date:
after 8/1/2026
Ending Date:
after 12/30/2028
Hours per Week:
40
Salary:
$3,000 per month
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
at least 1 year
Location:
Fort Collins, Colorado
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
A graduate assistantship for a master’s student is expected to be funded at Colorado State University (Fort Collins, CO) working with Dr. Brian D. Gerber (https://bgerber123.github.io/) at the Colorado Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit and wildlife researchers at Colorado Parks and Wildlife. The graduate research assistantship will cover university tuition, fees, health coverage, and includes a pre-tax monthly pay of $3000/month. The position is expected to start Fall 2026 and be funded through December 2028.

Study Context: Sex and age class are important demographic parameters used in population modeling, in which the results help guide management decisions and annual harvest quotas of large mammals (e.g., elk, bighorn sheep, pronghorn, mule deer). This work will help develop new methodology and workflows that will aid Colorado Parks and Wildlife’s objective of producing robust empirical demographic data and population estimates for harvested wildlife. 

Focus: The focus of this study will be to collect data on the size distribution of elk sex and age classes (cow, calf, bull) to train and test a predictive approach using AI algorithms (developed by Colorado Parks and Wildlife) to classify animals from high-resolution aerial imagery. Field observations and size measurements (via 3D camera) will be collected to help test the accuracy of AI predictions. An additional avenue of exploration may be data collection and AI classification of sex/age class from camera trap images. The student will be expected to develop a project proposal outlining study objectives in coordination with Colorado Parks and Wildlife and a graduate committee at Colorado State University. The student will focus on technological and software workflows to meet study objectives, however, there will likely be field work opportunities as well (e.g., field observations, drone/aerial surveys). Given the trajectory of the wildlife field, the skills gained in this study will likely be desirable for future employers. 

 Preferred Qualifications: 

-          Ungulate field research experience in the intermountain west
-          Clear interest or experience developing data analysis workflows
-          Clear interest or experience advancing technological innovation (hardware/software) in wildlife science
-          Experience deploying camera traps and managing large data sets
-          Experience with AI algorithms, for example MegaDetector or SpeciesNet
 
Minimum Qualifications:
-          A Bachelor of Science degree in wildlife ecology, biology, natural resource management, or related field
-          A year or more of wildlife related professional research/work experience
-          Strong writing skills
-          Strong work ethic 
-          Desire to collaborate with state wildlife management agencies

To be considered, please send the following materials via email with “AI/Elk Application” as the subject line to Dr. Brian D. Gerber (brian.gerber@colostate.edu) by March 2, 2026: 1) Cover letter outlining career goals, academic interests, and relevant experience related to the minimum and preferred qualifications, 2) resume with contact information for 3-4 personal references, and unofficial copy of B.S. transcripts. 

Contact
Brian D. Gerber

title: MS Assistantship: Pinyon Jay management, Deschutes County, Oregon. Masters of Natural Resources program, Oregon Tech, Klamath Falls, OR
description:
MS Assistantship: Pinyon Jay management, Deschutes County, Oregon. Masters of Natural Resources program, Oregon Tech, Klamath Falls, OR
Oregon Institute of Technology (State) | https://www.oit.edu/
Details
Posting:
https://jherimekellermann.weebly.com/
Application Deadline:
03/31/2026
Published:
02/18/2026
Starting Date:
between 2/28/2026 and 9/14/2026
Ending Date:
between 6/12/2028 and 8/1/2028
Hours per Week:
6 - 40
Salary:
starting at $18 per hour
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
at least 2 years
Location:
Oregon Tech (Klamath Falls, Oregon)
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
ROJECT TITLE: Pinyon Jay response to juniper management, Deschutes County, Oregon.

BACKGROUND: Pinyon Jays (PIJA, Gymnorhinus cyanocephalus) have experienced significant, range-wide declines over the past 50 years, and are currently under Status Review for ESA listing. Deschutes County, Oregon represents the northwestern-most extent of the species range and lies far outside the extant range of pinyon pine species. Extensive treatments of juniper woodlands have been expedited throughout western states for restoration of sagebrush ecosystems, sage grouse habitat, and altered fire regimes. However, we lack clear understanding of how these treatments impact PIJA populations.  

Management priorities for PIJA in Oregon include assessing impacts of juniper treatments on PIJA and determining state-wide distribution. The primary goals of this project are to experimentally study how juniper treatments impact occupancy, habitat use, and nesting of PIJA on BLM lands in Deschutes County, Oregon. We are implementing a before-after-control-impact study and use bioacoustics monitoring, point counts, and nest searching methods. The MS project will focus on at least one component of the project. This work is in partnership with the East Cascades Bird Alliance, US Fish and Wildlife, and Deschutes BLM. We also contribute to the PIJA Western Working Group and the PIJA Conservation Action Strategy (CAS). The MS candidate will be expected to coordinate with and contribute findings to larger range-wide intiatives. 

LOCATION & PROGRAM: This position supports a student in the Masters of Science in Natural Resources at Oregon Tech in Klamath Falls, OR. Our MS program started in 2024 and is in the Natural Sciences Department, which also encompasses the MS of Medical Science program, and BS programs in Environmental Science and Biology-Health Science. Program description and requirements are here https://www.oit.edu/academics/degrees/natural-resources 

SUPPORT: This position includes the opportunity for a Graduate Teaching Assistantship for the Academic Years 2026-2026 and 2027-2028. The GTA will teach labs in the 200-level Principles of Biology series for majors, &/or similar courses within the students expertise. GTAs cover two 3-hour sections per term. Oregon Tech is on a quarter system. Fall, Winter, and Spring terms are 11 weeks. Our academic year runs from mid-September to Mid-June.  The GTA provides a per-term stipend and partial tuition remission during the academic year (Fall through Spring terms). In addition, this research assistantship will provide additional part-time stipend during the spring term, and full-time hourly salary over the summer. Some travel costs from Klamath Falls to Bend, OR will be covered. The graduate student will be expected to use their own vehicle, preferably one that can handle rugged, rocky roads to access field sites. If the student would prefer to forgo the GTA position and cover their own academic costs, that would be an option. 

POSITION REQUIREMENTS: The candidate should have a Bachelors degree in Natural Resources, Wildlife, Ecology, Environmental Science or a closely related program of study and should meet the requirements for acceptance into the Masters of Natural Resources program at Oregon Tech. Ideally, the applicant will have at least 2 years of field experience studying birds, particularly nest searching and point counts. Experience with bioacoustics monitoring (ARUs, BirdNET) will be especially helpful. Additionally, experience doing habitat analyses (Occupancy modeling, RSFs, SDMs) using program R and GIS will be very valuable.  The candidate should have proven ability to work independently in remote areas, and as a member of a team, including supervising undergraduates and working with volunteers. 

 

DATES: Start date is flexible. We are beginning the greater project design and implementation this winter 2026, therefore, the candidate could start as early as March, 2026 as a temporary hire. The academic year begins in mid-September, 2026. 

LOCATION: Oregon Tech is in Klamath Falls, OR, a small rural region of south-central Oregon. The field research about 3 hours north, near Bend and Sisters, Oregon in the east Cascades, sage-steppe biome. This region is famous for its scenic beauty, biodiversity, and outdoor recreation including hiking and trail running, mountain biking, skiing, and water sports.  

APPLICATIONS: Please email a cover letter detailing your experience, interest in the project, and career goals, along with your CV to Jherime.kellermann@oit.edu ASAP.  We will review packages as they are received.

Contact
Jherime Kellermann
5418515156
jherime.kellermann@oit.edu (preferred contact method)

title: PhD Scholarship – Transforming Climate Action
description:
PhD Scholarship – Transforming Climate Action
Memorial University (Federal) | https://www.thelifeaquatic.xyz
Details
Posting:
https://thelifeaquatic.xyz/opportunities
Application Deadline:
05/31/2026
Published:
02/17/2026
Starting Date:
after 9/1/2026
Hours per Week:
at least 40
Salary:
starting at $30,000 per year
Education Required:
Masters
Experience Required:
none
Location:
St. John's, Canada
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
PhD Scholarship
Transforming Climate Action – Uncertain Seas 
 
A PhD Scholarship is available at the Centre for Fisheries Ecosystems Research, Fisheries & Marine Institute, Memorial University, St. John’s, NL, Canada.

Transforming Climate Action is a seven year, $397 million collaboration among Dalhousie University, Laval University, University Québec at Rimouski, and Memorial University. The largest research theme within Transforming Climate Action is Reducing Uncertainties in Carbon Cycling in the Northwest Atlantic Seas (Uncertain Seas). The goal of Uncertain Seas is to better constrain the role of the ocean in the Earth’s climate system by reducing uncertainties with physical and biogeochemical processes that control the global ocean carbon cycle. The focus is on the Northwest Atlantic gateway as a major contributor to ocean carbon uptake and sequestration, particularly with respect to the biological carbon pump.
We are seeking a PhD Student to estimate carbon fluxes in the Northwest Atlantic from Earth system and ecosystem models. As a part of Transforming Climate Action, there will be opportunities to participate in workshops with other graduate students from the four institutions. There will also be opportunities for research visits to collaborating labs and conference travel. There may be opportunities to participate in research expeditions, although not a requirement.  

Location: The student will be enrolled in the PhD in Fisheries Science graduate program at the Fisheries & Marine Institute, Memorial University, in St. John’s, NL, Canada.  Memorial University is a hub of ocean sciences located in the Province’s capital. St. John’s is a safe and friendly city with great historical charm, known for its hospitality, live music, a vibrant cultural life, and easy access to wilderness and a wide range of outdoor activities.

Requirements: 
 MSc or equivalent in Fisheries Science, Ecology, Statistics, Mathematics, Marine Ecology, Biology, Oceanography or related discipline 
 Demonstrated quantitative skills in ecosystem and/or statistical modelling
 Strong writing and communication skills

Start date: Flexible, ideally September 1, 2026

Stipend: $30K/year for four years

To apply: Please send a cover letter explaining your relevant experience to, and interest in, the project, CV with academic references (contact information, reference letters not required), and university transcripts to Dr. Tyler Eddy tyler.eddy@mi.mun.ca. If you have an interest in one of the four project areas, please elaborate in your cover letter.

Application deadline: Applications will be reviewed as received. To ensure that your application is given priority consideration, apply by May 31, 2026.
Contact
Tyler Eddy
tyler.eddy@mi.mun.ca (preferred contact method)

title: Graduate Assistantship at WVU: Aquatic Species Responses to Changing River Conditions
description:
Graduate Assistantship at WVU: Aquatic Species Responses to Changing River Conditions
Aquatic lab- West Virginia University (Private)
Details
Application Deadline:
04/01/2026
Published:
02/13/2026
Starting Date:
8/17/2026
Hours per Week:
at least 40
Salary:
$21,000 to $27,000 per year
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
at least 2 years
Location:
West Virginia University (Morgantown, West Virginia)
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
The Davis College of Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Design at West Virginia University, through Dr. Carol Arantes’s lab, is recruiting a Master’s or PhD student to begin in Fall 2026 to study how changes in river conditions affect aquatic ecosystems and biodiversity. 

The student will be part of a collaborative, interdisciplinary project examining how global hydraulic infrastructure and river management over the past century have altered river discharge regimes and aquatic ecosystems, and how uncertainty in reconstructed historical records affects confidence in global assessments of river change. Working within a multi-institutional research team, the student will collaborate closely with a modeling group to develop and apply new models and indicators of river processes that integrate hydrologic alteration, river fragmentation, sediment transport, river temperature, and patterns of fish diversity and abundance. 

The student will work closely with the PI, postdoctoral researchers, and a multi-institutional team of project partners to integrate ecological data with large-scale environmental and infrastructure datasets. Expected outcomes include peer-reviewed publications, technical reports, and presentations for both scientific and non-scientific audiences. The position offers strong training opportunities in quantitative analysis, interdisciplinary research, and professional development. 

Qualifications 
Applicants must hold a B.S. or M.S. degree in ecology, fisheries, zoology, aquatic sciences, or a closely related field, with a minimum GPA of 3.0/4.0. Successful candidates will demonstrate strong written and oral communication skills, solid analytical abilities, and the capacity to work independently and collaboratively. Experience or strong interest in fish and aquatic ecology is required. Experience with or interest in computer modeling, statistical analysis (Bayesian and/or frequentist approaches), and GIS is highly desirable. 

 Funding:
The selected student will be supported through a combination of Teaching Assistantships (TAships) and Research Assistantships (RAships), for a total of three years of funding.

M.S. students will receive a stipend of $21,000 per year plus a full tuition waiver.

Ph.D. students will receive 9 months of funding per year plus a full tuition waiver, with opportunities for additional summer salary contingent upon successful completion of stream surveys and project fieldwork.

 How to Apply
Interested students should email the following materials as a single PDF directly to:
Dr. Carol Arantes
caroline.arantes@mail.wvu.edu 

Application materials should include: 

A brief cover letter describing research background, interests, career goals, and motivation for pursuing an MS or PhD
A current CV or résumé
Names and contact information for three professional references
Unofficial transcripts and GRE scores (if available)

 Please do not submit materials to the WVU Graduate School at this stage.

Additional Information
 Davis College of Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Design
 https://www.davis.wvu.edu/
School of Natural Resources and the Environment
https://www.davis.wvu.edu/schools/natural-resources-and-the-environment
Dr. Arantes’s lab
https://www.davis.wvu.edu/faculty-staff/directory/carol-arantes
https://aranteslab.weebly.com/ 

 


  Contact
Caroline C. Arantes
caroline.arantes@mail.wvu.edu (preferred contact method)
